III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Financing and audit
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4108
Section (1) A licensee shall do all of the following:
Description (c) Demonstrate sufficient financing to assure that proper care of
residents is provided and that licensing rules are followed.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are financial concerns regarding the facility.
2

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 7/31/2024, separately. Youth A and Youth B reported
all their needs are being met at the facility. Both reported having
sufficient food to eat, therapy services, cloths that are clean and fit
appropriately, and activities to participate in. Youth A and Youth B
did report receiving spoiled milk at the facility and Youth B
indicated receiving expired snacks (this is being addressed under
special investigation 2024SIC0001629).
Youth C was interviewed via teams on 8/22/2024. Youth C
reported all his needs are being met at the facility. Youth C
reported he has all the hygiene products he needs and if he runs
out of something, he asks for more and receives more. Youth C
reported he has sufficient clothing at the facility that is clean and
fits him appropriately. Youth C has been at the facility for a month
and just received the level that will allow him to participate in off
grounds activities/outings. Youth C did not know what off
ground’s activities/outings consisted of or how frequent due to not
being able to participate.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 8/20/2024. Staff 1
reported having no concerns regarding the facility meeting youth
needs. Staff 1 reported youth’s medical needs, hygiene needs,
and treatment needs are being met. Staff 1 had no concerns with
staffing needs at the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/14/2024. Staff 2
reported having no concerns regarding the facility meeting youth
needs. Staff 2 reported youth receive all needed clothing, hygiene
products, treatment needs, and sufficient food. Staff 2 reported no
concerns with the facility.
Director of Operations was interviewed via telephone on
8/8/2024. Director of Operations reported no concerns with the
facilities ability to obtain food for the youth. The facility is
reimbursed for some of the food expense as the facility
participates in the National School Lunch Program and follows
USDA guidelines. Director of Operations reported the facility has
always been able to provide for the needs of youth.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/31/2024. Nurse reported the youths’ medical needs are being
met at the facility. There have been no issues with medications
arriving for youth.
3

Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 7/31/2024. Administrator reported she was not aware
of any financial concerns at the facility and all youth needs are
being met.
Financial Controller was interviewed via telephone at the
facility on 7/31/2024. Financial Controller reported the agency is
working on selling one of the properties that is no longer housing
youth and/or considering reopening the building. Financial
Controller reported the agency is moving in a positive direction as
the June financial statement was in the black meaning the facility
made profit. Financial Controller reported the agency financial
reports are progressively increasing however has varied year to
date. The agency had significant client damages to facilities
resulting in repairs needing to be made that the facility had not
anticipated including several broken windows.
Financial Controller, CEO, and Director of Adoption Services
were interviewed via teams on 8/22/2024. Financial Controller
reported the agency’s financial stability continues to improve. The
agency has changed the programming at two of the facilities
which created a slight decline in June and July 2024 however
August is now showing to be trending to the positive. The agency
has had no issues with making payments to staff or foster parents.
Currently the facility has a balance in the general fund account of
$2.1 million, $2.3 million in the money market, and a donation
account with a balance of $120,000. The main issue the agency
is facing is the Wolverine Secure Center building which has not
been licensed since 2021. The agency has a loan with Invesco
Lending for approximately $7 million. The agency is not behind or
in default on this loan. The agency has been working with Invesco
Lending and made a payment in November 2023 for $1 million.
The agency negotiated with Invesco Lending in October 2023 and
began making monthly payments of $10,000 and paid $783,000 in
back interest as Invesco Lending does not want the loan to default
as they do not want the building. Financial Controller reported the
Wolverine Secure Center building is costing $60,000 a month to
sit empty. The building has and currently is up for sale. Financial
Controller reported Invesco Lending is not foreclosing on the
Wolverine Secure Center and they have agreed to a forbearance
agreement. The $10,000 monthly payment to Invesco Lending is
not largely impacting the agency and that was why the amount
was determined and agreed upon.
4

In 2021 and 2022 the agency received funds from the State of
Michigan and the federal government which did not make up the
current debit that the agency had which prompted the agency to
restructure staffing. The facility had previously been overstaffed
and since COVID and restructuring, the facility in now better
managing staffing needs and aligning staffing more appropriately.
Financial Controller reported the facility audit review showed net
assets in decline which was a result of depreciation. The agency
removed $241,000 in depreciation by reducing unnecessary items
such as some agency vehicles, a leased property, building
equipment, and office equipment (terminated leases on copy
machines that were not needed). Financial Controller reported
although the audit findings of the current ratio of .69:1, the agency
would be able to pay off the Comerica loan if it came due
immediately through the funds in the money market account. The
Comerica loan remains to have a balance just shy of $2 million
which was from 2008 when Vassar House was built, and updates
were completed at the Vassar sites. The agency has and
continues to make monthly payments on this loan. If the Invesco
Lending loan came due today, the agency would not be able to
pay off the loan. The agency reported this would not occur due to
the agency coming to an agreement with Invesco Lending on
monthly payments.
CEO and Financial Controller reported the agency is meeting all
the youth needs at the facility and the financial stability of the
agency continues to not impact any of the youth’s needs.
Financial Controller reported loan payments are in good standing
as are utilities. Financial Controller reported the facility accrued a
lot of damages at the facilities with broken doors and windows.
The average cost of a door and door frame to be replaced is
$4,000-$5,000 and there had been approximately thirty to forty
doors as well as windows recently replaced in the last couple of
months.
Documents reviewed:
• Financial Memo provided by the Bureau of Audit: After
review of the Wolverine Human Services Audit Report for
the Fiscal Year Ending 9/30/2023 dated 7/30/2024 there
were concerns that the facility was in declining financial
condition. There was a decline in total net assets indicating
revenues exceed expenses as the agency has a decline in
net assets of 4.05%. There is negative working capital, and
a ratio of 0.69:1. A ratio under 1 suggests that the agency
5

could be unable to pay off its obligations if they came due
immediately.
• Wolverine Human Services Audit Report for the Fiscal Year
Ending 9/30/2023 dated 7/30/2024 noting ongoing
concerns of the agency’s financial stability. Prior to fiscal
year end, the agency had received approval for certain rate
per diem increases, re-opened certain residential
programs, and continues to list certain property for sale.
• Comerica Bank Loan Payment Notice dated 7/31/2024
showed the agency in good standing.
• Wolverine Human Services Statement of Activities-Current
Year Comparison to Budget for period ending 6/30/2024
showed in the positive for net assets.
• AP Aging Summary Spreadsheet for Utilities and Foster
Parents and leases demonstrating all payments have been
made that were due per the agency internal records.
• Vassar Water and Sewer Utility bill dated 9/3/2024 showed
the facility is up to date on payment.
• DTE bill for September 2024 showed the facility is up to
date with payment.
• Consumers Energy bill dated 9/3/2024 showed the facility
is up to date with payment.
• Repayment Agreement dated 10/18/2023 between
Wolverine Human Services and Invesco Lending states the
repayment agreement shall be effective from 10/18/2023
and shall continue through the repayment period.
• Email from Financial Controller dated 9/4/2024: The reason
for the auditor’s disclaimer response was attributed to the
lack of information as of the report date regarding the debt
resolution with the Wolverine Secure building as it was
undetermined at that time whether the agency was going to
sell or reopen another program at the site within the next
year. Financial controller included verification in the email
of payments to Invesco Lending.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews with staff and
youth, the facility’s financial stability is not impacting the facility’s
ability to staff appropriately, provide treatment programming, and
for the youth’s needs. The agency is in good standing with loans
and utilities as agreed upon payments are being made.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
